items.content_html: This PR removes the now-irrelevant WEBGL_compressed_texture_api from our documentation, to go along with its removal in BCD (see mdn/browser-compat-data#11763). The extension hasn't been supported in the last two years of browser releases, and was rejected from the spec, so it was abandoned before it became a part of standard track.
items.title: Remove unsupported `WEBGL_compressed_texture_atc` WebGL extension

items.content_html:

items.title: Correct aria-hidden default value

items.content_html: This PR removes the deprecated, no-longer-supported TouchList.identifiedTouch() method from the MDN content, to go along with its removal in BCD (see mdn/browser-compat-data#11760). The method is not supported in the last two years of releases in any browser, and has been dropped from the spec.
items.title: Remove unsupported `TouchList.identifiedTouch` method

items.content_html:
Based on testing:

  • these are the arguments which are actually passed to the callback function, and
  • the this argument which is available as an argument to .forEach() here.

What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

This information was missing and is data which is necessary in order to be able to use the described method.

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

I didn't check for an issue number. I encountered the page on MDN which didn't contain sufficient information to actually use the method which was being described.

Anything else that could help us review it

The formatting for the arguments and callback function arguments was taken from the Array pages, with the exception of not marking the arguments which are passed to the callback function as "optional", because they are not optional (i.e. they must be included when the .foreach() makes the call to the callback). Obviously, the callback doesn't have to do anything with any or all of the arguments, but that's the case for any called function, anywhere (well, at least in JavaScript).
items.title: Show arguments passed to callback & thisArg

items.content_html: With the one fixed in the two other PRs, this PR fix the remaining ones (if I have checked well).
items.title: Fix remaining code-in-pre flaws

items.content_html:
Window.clientInformation was added as an alias of Window.navigator in FF91. This adds

  • Entry for the alias in top level Window, which links to Window.navigator. This appears to be the model used for other alias cases - we don't duplicate all the docs at a lower level. I think this is all that is needed.
  • Release note entry.

Other work for this tracked in #6721
items.title: Window.clientInformation - add alias entry and release note

items.content_html:
Missing pages for CSSRuleList, also updated the interface page which was entirely different from other interface pages. Spec data PR has already been submitted.

Joe: there was a lengthy note on the interface page, I wasn't sure how necessary this was, though I guess a note that you can only get rules out of this object and not edit them is useful. I left the whole thing for now (just formatted it as a note) but let me know your thoughts.

Reviewer: @jpmedley
items.title: Adds missing CSSRuleList property and method pages.

items.content_html: Talking about these things in text is not very effective. I think you want an overview table of the identifiers you can use with optionalFeatures and requiredFeatures.

RTCDataChannelInit is a dictionary used only in createDataChannel. I anonymize it. (=== remove it).

With this, I'm finishing the RTCDataChannel rabbit hole.
items.title: Remove mentions of RTCDataChannelInit dictionary

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

document.createElement more accurately returns an HTMLElement instances. document.createElementNS is needed (unfortunately) for non-HTMLElement types, like SVGElement.

The built-in type definition in TypeScript also returns HTMLElement.

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: document.createElement returns an HTMLElement
